title: Sans with Swash
content:
For a book cover that need to be girly yet modern I’m wondering if anybody has any suggestions for sans serif fonts with swash characters.

Stewf, this is a good time for one of your fabulous lists!
author: pattyfab

comments.content: [Aspect](http://web.archive.org/web/20091110130225/http:/www.typography.net/type/aspect.htm) is visually fascinating but might not be girly enough for you.

William - that’s an intriguing font - I’ll consider it. Unfortunately my title doesn’t contain some of the more interesting characters.

I’d like to see fonts with swash capitals as well.

Check the [PDF for Aspect](http://web.archive.org/web/20091110130225/http:/www.typography.net/info/fonts/Aspect2B_Sample.pdf) for the swash caps. He shows them for about half the characters—though I wouldn’t be surprised if he has more than he shows.

Typecuts has a nice sans with swashes, though I don’t know if it’s for sale: [Broadway Hollywood Swash.](http://web.archive.org/web/20091110130225/http:/typecuts.com/fonts_view.php?kid=10&sid=51)

I’ve allways thought [Parisine Plus](http://web.archive.org/web/20091110130225/http:/www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/ParisinePlusPTF) is a bit girly.

\>Auto 3 have swash caps?

Ah, that’s it. That’s what I was remembering, but I got my wires crossed & thought it was Aspect—which is also fascinating, but more artsy and less natural. Auto 3 is great.

Nice! Right now I’m leaning a bit towards Aged, which I already own. It isn’t swashy but it is girly without being too twee. This needs to be a gift book but kitsch is not my thing. Anthropologie used Aged awhile back and that’s not a bad demographic to go for.

But keep the suggestions coming!
Dang that’s expensive! Only 3 weights for $120?
[Emily](http://web.archive.org/web/20091110130225/http:/www.t26.com/fonts/Emily) is charmingly girly without being too much, I think. (Click on the regular, not borders.)

What about [Coquette](http://web.archive.org/web/20091110130225/http:/ms-studio.com/FontSales/coquette.html) or [Lisboa Swash](http://web.archive.org/web/20091110130225/http:/vanarchiv.com/lisboa-swash.html) (which isn’t clearly available at Fountain yet, but might be soon from the looks of Ricardo Santos’ site)?
Or maybe [Titulata](http://web.archive.org/web/20091110130225/http:/www.tipo.net.ar/tipo_titulata_eng.html)? Though it’s not as feminine as some others.
Sauna? Or has that become passé already...?

’ [Mein Schatz](http://web.archive.org/web/20091110130225/http:/www.font-o-rama.com/fonts4sale/font_meinschatz/meinschatz.html)’, by Nina David, may be another alternate.

Dav(id)

I’d use Chianti for that purpose.

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/chianti/](http://web.archive.org/web/20091110130225/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/chianti/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/chianti/")

Thanks everybody for all the suggestions!

We left out Estilo

[http://www.dstype.com/estilo\_script.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20091110130225/http:/www.dstype.com/estilo_script.html "http://www.dstype.com/estilo\_script.html")
Has anyone released that Helvetica Flair yet?
